title: An in vitro Mechanical Damage Model of Isolated Myofibers in a Floating Culture Condition
procedures: Preparation before dissectionPrepare the materials needed for dissectionUsing a diamond pen, inscribe circles on glass Pasteur pipettes.Prepare the pipette openings with diameters of 1 mm (small) or 5 mm (large). For creating the large pipette, break the pipette at the circle (Figure 1).Heat-polish the cut ends of the Pasteur pipettes (both small and large) with a burner to prevent injuries to myofibers (Figure 1).Use a large pipette to disaggregate the EDL muscle bundle to individual myofibers.Then, use a small pipette to pick up and collect individual myofibers.Fit heat-polished pipettes with rubber bulbsimgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e4280/bioprotoc-12-01-4280-g001.jpgFigure 1. Workflow of making heat-polished pipettes (for large pipette). Prepare the disaggregation mediumImmediately before dissection, prepare 1 mL of 0.2% type I collagenase solution in DMEM containing 1% PS per EDL muscle into a 7 mL Bijou sample container.Sterilize the collagenase solution using a 0.45 μm syringe filter.Place the collagenase solution in a CO2 incubator at 37°C.Prepare 5% BSA solutionSterilize the BSA solution using a 0.45 μm syringe filter into a 25 mL self-standing tube.Inactivate the BSA solution at 60°C for 30 min in a water bath.Rinse the surface of all materials, including tubes, pipettes, and dishes with 5% BSA solution to prevent isolated individual myofibers from adhering.Prepare DMEM containing 1% PS for culture and washing of myofibers.Add 6-8 mL of DMEM containing 1% PS in each deep Petri dish and place in a CO2 incubator at 37°C before use.Prepare slide glasses enclosed on surface with pap-pen for immunostaining.Digestion of EDL muscle bundle to individual myofibers (Figure 2)Sacrifice 8-weeks-old C57BL/6 mice using cervical dislocation.Spray hindlimbs with 70% ethanol and remove the skin of the hindlimb.Using needles, pin both forelimb palm on a dissection board and cut the distal tendons of the EDL and tibialis anterior (TA) muscles.

Gently pull both the distal tendons of the EDL and TA muscles by tweezers toward the proximal direction.Remove the TA muscle.Expose the EDL muscle by removing connective tissues on the proximal tendon of EDL muscle.Carefully cut the proximal tendon of the EDL muscle, using a scalpel when the tendon is sufficiently exposed.Place the isolated EDL muscle into a 7 mL Bijou sample container containing prewarmed digestion medium and incubate for 1.5 h at 37°C under 5% CO2, gently shaking the tube every 15 min.Note: The appropriate digestion time depends on the size of the muscle and the enzymatic activity of collagenase. When the muscle becomes slightly swollen, and several individual myofibers are separated from the edge of the muscle, digestion should be completed. Repeat the same procedure for the other hindlimb if necessary.Note: Control intact and damaged myofibers should be used from the same mouse. imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e4280/bioprotoc-12-01-4280-g002.jpgFigure 2. Workflow of dissection of mice to isolate myofibers. Washing and collection of individual myofibersAll procedures should be performed using a stereo microscope in a tissue culture hood.Place the digested EDL muscles into the Petri dish filled with washing medium.Dissociate the muscle into individual myofibers using a large Pasteur pipette (pre-rinsed with 5% BSA) to triturate the muscle several times until it disaggregates.To further dissociate myofiber bundles into individual myofibers, triturate the bundles 2-3 times using a small Pasteur pipette (pre-rinsed with 5% BSA).Remove the hypercontracted myofibers, tendons, vessels, nerves, and other debris, by washing with washing medium. The number of washes depends on the amount of debris.Place individual myofibers in DMEM for 3 h at 37°C under 5% CO2 to eliminate dying hypercontracted myofibers (the 2nd incubation).Note: The 2nd incubation is important to obtain healthy undamaged myofibers. Damaged myofibers become hypercontracted during the incubation.

Co-culture of intact myofibers with damaged myofibers (Figures 3-4)All procedures should be performed using a stereo microscope in a tissue culture hood.Add DMEM into each well of a 6-well plate pre-coated with 5% BSA.Transfer 150 intact individual myofibers per well using a small Pasteur pipette.To remove the factors derived from damaged myofibers, aspirate DMEM using a small Pasteur pipette, and add fresh DMEM. Repeat this procedure several times. Do not aspirate DMEM completely not to dry myofibers. The volume of DMEM is determined as the ratio of 50 myofibers per mL.Collect 75 myofibers on the right side of the well using a small Pasteur pipette (Figure 3A).Apply mechanical damage directly to the collected myofibers by rolling the edge of a new Pasteur pipette (coated with 5% BSA and non-heat-polished) at least three times in the well (Figures 3B-3D).After applying mechanical damage to myofibers, damaged myofibers should shrink immediately, presenting a hypercontracted morphology (Figure 3E).Note: The Pasteur pipette is detached from damaged myofibers immediately after adding mechanical damage to the myofibers, because hyper-contracting damaged myofibers become sticky and coil easily around the pipette. Confirm that the ratio of intact (undamaged) myofibers to damaged myofibers is 1:1 using a stereo microscope. The total number of intact myofibers used as a control condition (non-co-culture damaged) must be equivalent to those in the damaged condition.Note: Myofibers tend to spread elsewhere during the damage process (Figures 3B-3D). In this case, the spread myofibers are re-collected and damaged again. To relocate damaged myofibers between intact myofibers, flush the medium with a small Pasteur pipette (Figure 3F). If hypercontracted myofibers are found in the control condition, remove them as soon as possible to minimize the influence of DMDFs on the intact healthy myofibers.

Note: In the undamaged control condition, aspiration of the culture medium should be minimized when damaged myofibers are washed out. imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e4280/bioprotoc-12-01-4280-g003.jpgFigure 3. Workflow of co-culture of intact myofibers with damaged myofibers in a floating condition. imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e4280/bioprotoc-12-01-4280-g004.jpgFigure 4. Representative images of undamaged (left) and damaged (right) conditions. Immunostaining (Figures 5-6)The stereo microscope should be used during manipulation of myofibers.Coat the inside of 1.5 mL tubes and a small Pasteur pipette with 5% BSA to prevent myofibers from adhering.Transfer the myofibers into a 1.5 mL tube using a small Pasteur pipette and remove the excess amount of medium.Note: Transferred myofibers fall down to the bottom of the tube within 5 min. To fix the myofibers, add 2% PFA in PBS to the 1.5 mL tube containing myofibers. The final concentration of PFA would be less than 2%.Wash the myofibers three times with a washing solution (PBS-T: 0.025% Tween 20 in PBS). After myofibers are all gathered to the bottom, the washing solution is carefully replaced with a small Pasteur pipette.Permeabilize with a permeabilization solution (0.3% Triton X100 in PBS) for 20 min at room temperature (15-25°C).Wash once with washing solution.Block with a blocking solution (5% goat serum in PBS-T) for 20 min at room temperature (15-25°C).Wash three times with washing solution.Incubate with appropriate primary antibodies diluted in PBS-T at 4°C overnight.Wash three times with washing solution.Incubate with the appropriate species-specific Alexa Fluor 488 and/or 546 fluorescence-secondary antibodies in PBS-T for 60 min at room temperature (15-25°C).Wash the cells twice with PBS-T and then wash once with PBS, to promote the attachment of myofibers onto the glass slide.Enclose the surface at the edge with a pap-pen, to prevent myofibers from leaking out from the glass slide, and transfer the myofibers to the glass slide.

Remove the excess amount of PBS from the surface of the slide glass.Mount the cover glass onto the slide glass with a drop (~50 µL) of mountain medium containing DAPI.Stick the cover glass and the slide glass together with transparent nail polish at the four corners.Image the samples under fluorescence microscope and analyze using the cellSens softwareimgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e4280/bioprotoc-12-01-4280-g005.jpgFigure 5. Representative immunofluorescence images of an activated satellite cell (PAX7+/MYOD+) associated with an intact healthy myofiber co-cultured with damaged myofibers for 48 h. Scale bars, 50 µm.imgsrc:https://en-cdn.bio-protocol.org/attached/image/e4280/bioprotoc-12-01-4280-g006.jpgFigure 6. Representative immunofluorescence images of contamination of interstitial cells (CD31+ or CD45+) associated with intact healthy myofibers in the unpurified condition. Scale bars, 50 µm.
